text: left side upper back strain employee reports while testing road compaction using a sledge hammer when employee noticed pain to left side of upper back. workcare contacted, internal documentation started.

employee communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19  an employee reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19 to site management. the employee has been in isolation since october 10th. wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed. this is the third positive result for the 11th  of october.

category: dropped object or material, hand or arm injury
text: cut to hand the security person for the project picked up a box that had been dropped off by a courier.  the box was for the client water treatment plant and contained a floor scraper.  part of the scraper blade, which was not guarded, poked out through the side of the box when the employee picked it up for moving into the shack.  the worker obtained a cut to the palm of the right hand. the wound was cleaned and dressed following standard first aid practices.

category: vehicle Incident involving animal, lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: while driving home from jobsite at 8:00 pm, truck struck 3 deer as they attempted to cross hwy 128 in illinois.  no injuries - all 3 wgm employees buckled in, front grill of truck damaged. migrated from legacy cairs incident #29052on friday, march 18, 2016, while driving home from work at approximately 8:00 pm, driver of truck struck 3 deer that jumped into roadway from ditch. since it was dark, driver did not see the deer until they were directly in front of vehicle. attempted to stop, but vehicle struck all 3 deer causing damage to grille, hood and bumper of truck. police were notified and report was filed. no injures reported - vehicle was still drivable. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: environmental leak or issue, excavations, line strike
text: subcontractor - natural gas release incident  a natural gas subcontractor, while installing a natural gas riser, in a trench box (4ft excavation) failed to verify isolation and cut into a four inch line (using a sawz all – cold cut method/non spark producing) that released natural gas (low pressure).  all work was stopped as soon as line was breached.  emergency notifications were made and isolation was conducted on the gas line.  a safety stand down was held on may 17th, 2019 and additional stand down is being held on may 20th to review the incident and learning's to date.  a training class and review of natural gas piping purging and equipment installations will be conducted with site subcontractor focal points and supervisors.   the client on site is conducting a joint investigation with wood site hsse and supervision involved.
4 unrelated ips tested +ve for covid 4 unrelated ips tested +ve for covid ip isolated. no ccs

the forks reached beneath the pipe which was supported by wood pads (10 cm cubic), the pipe was slid forward onto the concrete road at about 09:40, a.m. sep.6th, 2018, on the road south to the eto plant, there was one pipe with dn 24 inches, 4.3m long and 445kg (600*7mm*0.02466*4.3?lying on the road. the forklift operator mr. chen was assigned to move this pipe to the stacking area, and mr. liu yi fei is a trained flagman and he was responsible for directing the forklift operator, meantime the work crew foreman mr. yang jian feng and another worker were standing at aside of both ends of the pipe for supporting. when the forks reached beneath the pipe which was supported by wood pads (10 cm cubic), the pipe was slid forward onto the concrete road, which made a collision noise. about 10:35 a.m., because the civil contractor needed the location for pouring concrete and the pipe shall be removed away. then, a piece of 2t lift web and the 5t forklift were used for lifting the pipe up a little up the road and 2 pieces of wood pads (10c cubic) were laid under the pipe, and wood pins were used for stopping the pipe from rolling. a 25t crane was used for lifting the pipe onto the forklift and secured with ropes with the forklift and the flagman guided the forklift to the stacking area.

a wood group hv operator reported to the site clinic on saturday night complaining of foot pain. migrated from legacy cairs incident #32229a wood group hv operator (ssw) took himself to the site clinic on saturday evening seeking treatment for pain being experienced in his foot, none of which had been reported to his work supervisor. during conversations, he revealed that he had experienced an issue involving his foot (stepping on a rock or edge of concrete) at hq3 at approximately 1:30pm friday 03 feb 17 friday afternoon and this was the only potential triggering incident that he could recall. the details about the issue he experienceddiffered onrepeat questioningin the worker's recollection.as part of investigations into the report, it was revealed that the worker stated on several occasions that he experienced no pain whatsoever when he experienced the potential triggering event and continued and finished his shift without issue/foot pain. the worker also reported that he then attended the site gymnasium where he was observed by others training with no appearance of any foot related issue at all. the worker attended work the next morning again with no issue with his foot and worked as per normal until his supervisor noted him limping that afternoon and challenged him about this and if he required a visit to the site clinic. the worker said he had no issue and no need to visit the site clinic and continued working. later that shift he did experience some foot pain (without incident) and took himself to the bus without telling his supervisor. after arrival back at site, he went to his room and sourced some food from others from the canteen when he eventually decided to visit the site clinic again without notifying his supervisor and wg were informed.the worker's foot was x-rayed with no fracture identified and diagnosed with a soft-tissue injury, initially linked to his story of stepping on a rock.both client and wg evaluation has determined the issue to be non-work related. · the initial event linked to the injuryoccurred on 3/2/2017 @ approx. 14.30. it was not reported with no witnesses to the event.. the ip stated there was no pain experience when this occurred.· the ip completed his shift on friday 1800 had dinner and went to the gym where he was observed doing weight training and bike riding. no signs of pain or distress. ip stated he had no pain while at gym.· 4/2/2017. the ip attended pre-start (no report) and went up to hq3 where he performed his duties, moving he vehicles as required and assisting mechanics.· the ip worked till lunchtime and after lunch went about his normal duties (no pain, no report).· at 1430 he was observed by his foreman to have a limp and the question was asked about going to the clinic. he declined however went to rest in the bus at 1600 – 1700 hours without notifying his foreman. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

the wood employee was tested offshore and show positive result for covid. the wood employee was tested offshore and show positive result for covid. he is asymptomatic. isolation and medical recommendation.

ee tested positive for covid-19 ee was in contact with a family member that tested positive for covid-19. ee was sent home due to potential exposure to the virus and began showing symptoms of cough on june 20th, followed by body aches on june 22nd. ee tested for covid-19 on june 26th; positive results came back on june 30th.  contact tracing has been conducted as ee has not been at the job site since june 16th. ee is scheduled to take next covid-19 test on july 28th.

category: bites (animals or insects), hand or arm injury, head or face injury
text: employee recieved 2 insect bites to his cheek while working employee states that he was in the fab area of the unit #2 and felt something on his face, and then felt a stinging and burning sensation on his right cheek similar to that of an insect bite. after removing his gloves, the employee then felt his face with his hand and noticed a bump. the employee then immediately reported the incident to his supervisor and was brought to safety for evaluation and treatment.  though no insect was seen, visible swelling and redness was observed in 2 places on the employees right cheek. the area was cleaned and sterilized with an alcohol wipe, insect sting relief ointment was applied for comfort, followed by triple antibiotic ointment for irritation. employee was released and advised to not irritate the area, and report back after lunch. follow-up after lunch showed noticeable improvement to swelling and redness to the area.

worker was walking through the plant after leaving his job and went to lunch when a fall is generated.  worker was walking through the plant after leaving his job and went to his place of lunch when a fall is generated that generates pain in the left knee, he went for medical evaluation and we are waiting for results from the specialist wood, enel and tc33's management meeting with the entire project team to socialize the event.to perform a general inspection of the gratings throughout the unit.meeting with wood's internal project team

a wood employee has been tested positive to covid-19 a milan employee has been tested positive to covid-19. the ip was completely asymptomatic; he did the test before to take a flight and the result confirmed he's positive. the ip is currently in isolation, in good health conditions. no further actions are necessary as no close contacts with other employee occurred.

managed contractor employee tested positive for covid-19 managed contractor employee tested positive for covid-19. this is understood to be a community transmission.  managed contractor employee entered period of self-isolation as per government requirements.

excavator bottom windshield was broken while breaking lime-stone with a hammer  on saturday march 19th, 2022, around 17:15, crew was still performing pile remediation. during this operation, the operator discovered limestone rock. therefore, the operator had to use an excavator hammer attachment to break the rock. while the operator was hammering the limestone rock a piece of rock hit the bottom windshield. this contact caused the bottom tempered glass to break. the actual and potential severity rating is an a1 since damage is minor (less than 10k) and spotter was in a safe distance behind the red barricade. the incident was immediately reported to the superintendent. incident investigation protocols were put in place by operations and hsse site team. the jsa was closed, scene was frozen, photos of the incident were gathered. the employees were escorted to the safety office for statement and ua screening collected.

vehicle made contact with bollard vehicle was dropping off some material to some co-workers. they stopped to look around and then went to drive off and contacted the bollard.   reported to supervisor and took photos and statements

two male teenagers (ages 13-16) found trespassing at the back of the premises. migrated from legacy cairs incident #32235at 17:16thesecurity guard(johan van jaarsveld) noticed two male teenagers (ages 13-16) on camera 4. one of the boys climbed over the terrace gate at the top of the stairs and walked all the way to the railing by camera 3 and back again, all this happened at the back of the building by the canteen.the security guardintercepted them by gate 7 through the undercroft and informed them that this building is private property and they shouldn't be here, they acknowledged the fact and left. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: head or face injury, foot or leg injury, general injury, vehicle incident general
text: wood employee was driving on a lease road when he came in contact with a calf that cross his path. impact caused damage to the wood vehicle headlight. wood employee was not injured as a result of this incident. migrated from legacy cairs incident #34760wood employee was driving on a lease road when he came in contact with a calf that crossed his path. wood vehicle struck the hip of the calf with his bumper and the impact caused damage to the wood vehicle headlight.wood employee was not injured as a result of this incident. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury employee was traveling to a job site in lehi, utah and collided with the rear end of another vehicle when the string of vehicles in front of employee braked rapidly. internal reporting initiated.

dangerous occurrence - sling ignited during hwnf preparations hot work naked flame (hwnf) work had started on 16th sept using lifting gear to install caisson. location is fire pump one housing (east side), on the hydrocarbon free blp. a non pressurized safehouse habitat had been erected as per hazid. habitat was constructed with port in roof section to allow lifting gear controls and lifting chain through. these were for the initial lifting of the caisson into position and were not required for the deck plate welding task.at 03:15 on 21/09/16, nightshift were preparing to weld down deck plate section around caisson. plate required pre-heat using propane as per the weld procedure specification. propane was ignited from stick welding arc. this required powering up the welding set, which is located remotely from fire pump one housing on the west side of the blp.at some point the control line wire had been parted previously. strands at both ends were fused together. set was powered and rod / holder came in contact with wire support that runs the length of the red rooster control lines.wire drew current and began to glow, wire was in direct contact with a soft sling that was used as part of the caisson installation. soft sling ignited and this was spotted by the firewatcher. welder left fire pump housing to shut off welding set. firewatcher used foam extinguisher on soft sling. habitat was made safe and task suspended.

massy wood employee tested positive for covid 19 virus massy wood employee tested positive for covid 19 virus during pre-entry screening at the hotel accommodation. employee was subsequently transported home to self quarantine.

wgpacs employee was checking a wellhead when a wasp flew out from underneath the electrical box and stung him on the back of the neck. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31265wgpacs employee was checking a wellhead when a wasp flew out from underneath the electrical box and stung him on the back of the neck. axiom was contacted and first aid measures were appropriate for the this incident. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: security or general safety concern, general illness or health issue
text: ip had visited the clinic in the morning reporting a health issue, however since the ip had been to the clinic previously for the same issue - isos doctor decided to send ip to the hospital at lapaz for further testing/evaluation. migrated from legacy cairs incident #34411ip had visited the clinic in the morning reporting a health issue, however since the ip had been to the clinic previously for the same issue - isos doctor decided to send ip to the hospital at lapaz for further testing/evaluation. will update as more information is made availablethe staff atla paz conducted an ekg, as well as an ultrasound and further evaluation from a cardiologist. an abdominal/chest scan was carried out to determine the cause of the pain. it was concluded that ip had gallbladder stones and his gallbladder is inflamed and will be held overnight at la paz for further evaluation. during this time, he will be given and iv, antibiotics and pain medication as needed. he will need his gallbladder removed, but has noted he does not want to have the surgery performed here, but rather back in thailand with his normal doctors. project manager is to discusswith the clinic; the isos doctor does not believe there will be much risk – just more of pain management andip can fly commercial. 17 august 2017isos doctor at punta europa clinic requested the ip be flown home on a commercial flight without a medical escort.ip was signed fit to fly by the same doctor.ip was advised to wait 7 days after arriving home to seek further medical evaluation, unless he suffers further symptoms before that time period. 18 august 2017ip departed for his home location on ethiopian airlines to bangkok via addis ababa. houston hr are to contact ip to receive regular updates. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

joining instructions for compass point office (staines) migrated from legacy cairs incident #33848email for client 10/05/17on my arrival at heathrow last friday i followed the joining instructions provided by wood group:since i had some luggage to carry i chose to arrange a taxi to reduce my risks on 1. strain on back, 2. potential target for theft…. i arranged a taxi with staines cars and received some “vague instructions on how to meet them… something like meet them at the ground floor lift of the car park, but they would come to me if i called them”.anyway i didn’t worry about it too much because this is london heathrow.i arrived and there was no one waiting for me with a sign with my name at the arrival door… i proceed to the lift in the car park and could not find any car with a “staines” sign on it… i called them and they said they would be there in 15-20 minutes. i waited for 30 minutes as i roamed back and forth from the arrival door where pick up taxi reps were standing to the car park… after 30 minutes i called again and no answer… so i started to enquire about bus routes to staines. i was just starting to look for the bus pick up point when the security guard came running from the car park and told me a taxi with staines written on it had parked in the car park… after a quick check, i confirmed it was my taxi which was over 45 minutes late from the point of calling.on the way to the hotel i asked the taxi driver why they don’t wait inside the arrival hall with a sign showing the client’s name like all the other taxi services do… i was informed they had lost their license to pick up people from heathrow.on reflection i should have done more to make sure they would have been waiting at the arrival door with a sign to make this a less frustrating experience (and safer). however i would also expect wood group to regularly check their joining instructions and verify that the listed taxi services have licenses to pick up clients and will wait at the arrival door with client’s name.i have only highlighted above the hse concerns, but could write a much more extensive email on the all the additional risks i took on that day when i arrived and there was no one waiting at the arrival door with a sign. i.e. this isn’t a “benefit” which clients are looking for… it is a basic safety requirement for people who are not oriented to the environment and do not know how to get from point a to point b. for example we take business trips to london heathrow lightly but consider if waiting in a car park in houston or manilla which would have raised my risk profile significantly higher since it is very easy to be either mugged or even kidnapped in those locations.i trust wood group will take the necessary actions to review their joining instructions and ensure it is kept up to date on a regular basis. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

individual with positive covid-19 individual received first symptoms of headache on 15nov2020 due to that was working remotely on the 18nov2020 lost sense of smell and taste tested on 19nov2020 with positive result of pcr test on 20nov2020. subcontractor informed wood safety representative on test result. conducted contact tracing with result of 6 close contacts. subcontractor decided to conduct initial pcr test for the close contacts. contact tracingisolation of close contactsinitial pcr test for close contacts

category: general injury, mechanical or equipment issue, fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was standing on the fender of a side-dump trailer using a torque wrench to loosen a pipe when the torque wrench broke and he fell approximately 4 feet to the ground. he hit his head, lost consciousness, and suffered facial cuts and broken ribs, requiring hospitalization.

category: foot or leg injury, lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle in nonroadway area, unspecified while performing duties as a valet, an employee was walking to the designated valet service parking lot to retrieve a customer's vehicle and was struck from behind by a pickup truck.  the employee was knocked down and his left leg was run over. the employee sustained a broken left tibia, three broken toes on the left foot and torn tendons in the left leg.

category: dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury, vehicle incident general
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was loading a truck cab on a trailer while the tongue of the trailer was being held up by a jack. while moving the trailer, the jack slipped off the trailer tongue, partially amputating the employee's right pinky finger.
nonclassifiable an employee injured his left-hand finger while changing the tire on a rim.
exposure to environmental heat an employee suffered from heat stroke after working outside with asphalt.

category: back injury, head or face injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  on february 29, 2020, a sales employee entered a tire service bay and tripped over a pneumatic air hose, striking his head on a wall.  he suffered a head laceration and two fractured vertebrae and was hospitalized.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was loading molding into a machine. the employee's gloved hand was caught in the machine as the blade was coming to a stop. the right middle fingertip was amputated with bone loss.

struck by object or equipment dropped by injured worker an employee was lifting a hatch to gain access to the underground area. as he was lifting the hatch, his right pinky finger was caught between the hatch and the ground amputating it at the first knuckle.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified while an aircraft was preparing for departure, a ramp service employee was conducting a physical walk-around safety check. he noticed that the forward wing slat was deployed and a piece of rubber stripping was protruding. as the employee attempted to push the rubber back in, the slat retracted, trapping his hand. the employee's right index fingertip was amputated at the nail cuticle.

category: dropped object or material, foot or leg injury, lifting or moving loads
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee was moving a stack of small beams from one area to another to clear space using an overhead crane. he set the material down and went to pull the chain from between the beams when the hook caught one of the beams. the stack toppled over and trapped his left leg. he was hospitalized with a fractured left leg.

category: hand or arm injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was finishing drywall seams on the fourth floor corridor ceiling when he fell to the concrete below. he suffered a right-side facial laceration and broken right arm.

caught in running equipment or machinery, unspecified on or about january 13, 2015, at about 8:05 p.m., a temporary worker was hospitalized for a compound fracture. his arm got caught in and crushed by the rubber bucket mill rollers after his sleeve became caught in the machinery. he has had surgery for the injuries sustained.  he was employed by aerotek, inc. and placed at the trelleborg wheel systems dba maine industrial tire llc red lion worksite.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was operating a jointer machine when the employee's left hand was pulled into the machine, partially amputating the middle finger.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to slipping  a temporary employee was walking in a cooler with a temperature of -25 degrees when he slipped and fell, breaking his left ankle.

overexertion involving outside sources, unspecified in either pulling down an elevator door or installing a 5- to 10-pound vibrator on a carbon scale, an employee suffered an abdominal hernia.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation on july 8, 2016, at approximately 1:15 pm, an employee was bending pieces of metal in a pneumatic parts bender. when he attempted to remove a part from the machine, the pneumatic bending piston crushed and amputated his right index fingertip just below the nail.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation a temporary employee was removing a part from a neck down machine when the machine was activated via the foot control. his left middle fingertip was then caught and amputated in the machine's nip point.
struck by or caught in swinging door or gate an employee's left index finger was amputated when it was caught in a door jam.

struck by object or equipment, unspecified an employee was on a lift, welding a clip on the outer side of a building at about the fourth-floor level. the elevator came down and contacted his right hand, cutting the wrist. he was hospitalized, undergoing surgery to the wrist.

category: dropped object or material, hand or arm injury
text: struck by falling part of powered vehicle still attached an employee was helping to set a concrete lid weighing a couple hundred pounds for an electrical box in place. one end of a length of steel chain was attached to a steel loop (hasp) embedded in the concrete lid.  the employee attempted to attach the other end of this chain to a steel loop (hasp) on the back (underside) of an excavator bucket when the excavator boom unexpectedly dropped, pinning the employee's right thumb between the bottom of the excavator bucket and the concrete lid. his right thumb was amputated at a point between the first and second knuckle.
struck by or caught in swinging door or gate an employee's pinky fingertip was amputated in a door jamb when the door shut.

ignition of vapors, gases, or liquids an employee was performing a calibration to test sulfur content in butane. the valve was stuck so he used a wrench and butane sprayed out and ignited in the lab. the employee suffered second and third degree burns to his arms and face and was hospitalized.

category: head or face injury, dropped object or material, line strike, vehicle incident general
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part a bundle of piping was being moved with a crane, with an employee holding onto the tagline to guide the bundle through an opening. a pipe was dislodged from the bundle and struck the employee in the forehead, knocking the employee unconscious and causing an open laceration and a small skull fracture above the eye. the employee was hospitalized.

other fall to lower level less than 6 feet on may 19, 2021, an employee was responding to a road call and had just arrived at the scene. he fell as he stepped out of the tractor cab and he landed on the ground, suffering a hip fracture.

category: general injury, hand or arm injury
text: caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee's upper left arm was surgically amputated at the shoulder after it was pulled into the cubing machine during sanitation.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was operating the press. the employee observed that there was no water on the water form roller tray. as the employee was checking the water supply, the employee's left index and middle fingers were caught and amputated by the water form roller.

category: head or face injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level, n.e.c.  an employee was carrying a cake when she lost her balance, falling to her knees and hitting her head.
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was removing a jammed stick from a band saw when the saw blade amputated the end of the employee's left index finger.

category: foot or leg injury, vehicle incident general
text: pedestrian struck by forward-moving vehicle in nonroadway area an employee carrying a tote walked up to the large trash compactor to dump the tote contents. a coworker rolled up a pallet jack carrying a large box to the compactor and struck the employee, pushing him into the trash compactor. the employee's right upper leg broke, requiring hospitalization.

fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was case picking when she tripped over a piece of wood sticking out of a pallet on the floor. she fell to the concrete floor, suffering broken vertebrae.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was moving kegs and a pallet onto a truck when a keg slid into another keg and crushed the employee's left middle finger, resulting in a partial finger amputation.

direct exposure to electricity, unspecified an employee was pushing electrical wire through an underground conduit. the electrical wire arc-flashed with a switch gear and the employee sustained burns to the hands and face.

struck by falling part of powered vehicle still attached on september 27, 2017, an employee and coworkers were attempting to load a crane onto a truck when the lifting strap broke and an outrigger fell on the employee's leg, resulting in a partial amputation below the knee.
exposure to environmental heat an employee was shoveling asphalt when he began to feel unwell. he was hospitalized for heat exhaustion/dehydration.

struck by discharged object or substance on august 3, 2017, at approximately 9:00 a.m., an employee was tending a well while standing between two gas production units approximately 15 feet from a sand separator. at that time, a threaded pipe that was going into the top of the sand separator blew apart. the pipe separated at a 90 degree elbow and released approximately 2,300 lbs. of pressure. the gas from the line projected down towards the ground and the employee's skin was struck by ground debris. he was hospitalized.

fall or jump from vehicle in normal operation, roadway an employee was injured after abandoning a moving vehicle during transport for repair. the car had failed brakes and no brake fluid at the time. the employee landed on concrete and was hospitalized.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fall, slip, trip, unspecified  while unloading merchandise for delivery, an employee stepped on an unseated dock plate and suffered a right leg fracture. the employee was hospitalized.
injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was cutting wood stakes out of 2x4s with a hand saw and lacerated a finger on the left hand.
